author: stsp
msg: represents the store-passwords option to also represent the
store-auth-creds option. This made it look at first glance
as if the store-passwords option was equivalent to the
--no-auth-cache command line option, which isn't true.

author: stsp
msg: On the dont-save-plaintext-passwords-by-default branch, default to
not storing plaintext passwords on disk.
Users now have to explicitly tell Subversion to save plaintext
passwords, either via a configuration file setting, or by passing
This still needs to be refined. Karl wants another command line
option equivalent to the dont-store-passwords directive in the
svn_cmdline_setup_auth_baton. Takes a new parameter and reads a
new configuration file option, both indicating whether storing
plaintext passwords is allowed. This information is fed into
with store_plaintext_passwords set to TRUE. This means the old
behaviour of storing plaintext passwords by default is retained
for clients using the old API.
(simple_save_creds_helper): Only store passwords by default for
providers encrypting passwords. Currently this means that only
the wincrypt and keychain providers store passwords by default.
I opted for listing the providers allowed to store passwords by
default explicitly, rather than simply disallowing password storing
for the "simple" provider. This approach is safer, because if new
providers are added in the future that store passwords in plaintext,
we don't want them to slip through the cracks accidentally.
call this --store-plaintext-passwords but this was too wide for
(main): Handle new command line option, and pass it on to

author: fabien
msg: (): fix one --accept value for 'svn resolve' command, and more

author: hwright
msg: (tx_body_file_checksum): Don't default to the empty checksum if SHA1
(base_file_checksum): Directly return the error from the last function call.
